newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian rupee ends steady as RBI buys dlrs at 35.70.
newsitem.headline: Indian rupee ends steady as RBI buys dlrs at 35.70.

text.p: Central bank dollar purchases helped the Indian rupee close steady at 35.7000/7050 on Wednesday, a day when the U.S. currency firmed across the board, setting a 47-month high against the Swiss franc, dealers said.
Most of the day's deals were at 35.700/7025 rupees to a dollar, dealers said.
The central Reserve Bank of India (RBI) hit the market in late afternoon, buying dollars at 35.7000 and 35.7050, dealers said.
Dealers said the spot dollar-rupee market had become dull in the absence of fresh market-moving factors.
Most dealers said they did not expect any major movement in the exchange rate until the end of September.
"I see a lot of inflows over the next three months," Arun Dobe, director (forex) at Bank of America, said.

"Demand would pick up by October/November if IOC (Indian Oil Corporation) enters the market (to buy dollars to pay for its oil imports)," he said. IOC has been funding oil imports through offshore loans as the government owes its over 100 billion rupees in unpaid dues for subsidising sales of oil products.
"But I don't see the rupee going below the 35.60-mark," Dobe said. He said the rupee should move in the 35.60/80 band over the next few months.
On Wednesday, the forward premiums ended a shade down as overnight call rates showed signs of easing, dealers said.
But the movement was on thin volumes, they added.
"There won't be volumes until fresh factors emerge to move the market," a dealer at a foreign bank said.
The six month annualised forward premium closed the day at 3.64 percent compared to the previous close of 3.70 percent.
